text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Organized economic crime and an Italian mafia organisation have set up in Albania, according to a study by the prosecutor's office.
- Alleged pyramid schemes proliferating in Albania could be a conduit for money laundering by the Italian-Albanian mafia.
- Albania and Italy vowed to stop the illegal inflow of would-be-immigrants, fight organized crime and traffic in drugs and prostitutes.

- The Tirana section of the opposition Socialist Party wants the sacking of jailed leader Fatos Nano, the resignation of its presidency and the staging of a new congress. The party was routed in a local ballot last October.
- Albanian civil servants are declaring their finances, a process that will sift through the properties of 22,000 officials. The commission in charge complained it cannot investigate bank accounts.
- Albania's consumer price index fell 0.5 percent in November compared to October but inflation in 1996 is far higher than the government had hoped.
- Albanian President Sali Berisha hails the country's youth day, December 8th, which marks the day six years ago when Albanian students revolted and overthrew communism.

- The International Monetary Fund has told Albania to watch alleged pyramid schemes so they do not become part of a black money network, said Finance Minister Ridvan Bode. He ruled out that such companies were engaged in money laundering.

- Finance Minister Ridvan Bode warned Albanians to think twice before investing in alleged pyramid schemes, to choose the more secure schemes because the state would not take responsibility if they collapsed.
